title: 104_s1200
content: The Act may be cited as the "Freedom and Human Rights for the Enclaved People of Cyprus Act". The Congress emphasizes the importance of promoting human rights, especially in allied countries, through foreign assistance. It aims to end restrictions on freedoms and human rights for the enclaved people of Cyprus, including limitations on worship and communication. The enclaved people of Cyprus face restrictions on communication, possession of telephones, leaving the area without permission, censorship of mail, reporting requirements for males aged 18 to 50, and limitations on educational services. The enclaved people of Cyprus face restrictions on communication, possession of telephones, leaving the area without permission, censorship of mail, reporting requirements for males aged 18 to 50, limitations on educational services, lack of replacement elementary school teachers and facilities beyond elementary school, restrictions on leaving home for education, violation of property rights, and lack of compensation for work performed. The enclaved people of Cyprus face restrictions on communication, possession of telephones, leaving the area without permission, censorship of mail, reporting requirements for males aged 18 to 50, limitations on educational services, lack of replacement elementary school teachers and facilities beyond elementary school, restrictions on leaving home for education, violation of property rights, lack of compensation for work performed, harassment, beating, rape, and murder without adequate protection or investigation. The United States is working to alleviate and eliminate restrictions on the enclaved people in Cyprus. The President is required to inform the United Nations and foreign governments about restrictions on the enclaved people of Cyprus, seek international assistance to end these restrictions, and establish US assistance programs for the enclaved. The US government is allocated funds to assist the enclaved people of Cyprus by eliminating restrictions on their freedom and human rights, as well as helping them reclaim ancestral homes and lands. The US government aims to support individuals forcibly expelled or fleeing Cyprus due to freedom and human rights violations. The President notifies foreign governments participating in these restrictions and urges them to cease involvement. The Secretary of State is responsible for monitoring and reporting on these issues. The Secretary of State will report on the enclaved people of Cyprus in the annual Department of State's Country Reports on Human Rights Practices. The President will direct the US representative to the UN to urge action on the enclaved people in Cyprus and call for an investigation and corrective measures by the UN Human Rights Commissioner.
